title: Domain 1.4: Explain common networking ports, protocols, services, and traffic types.
content:
ğŸ“¤ File Transfer Protocol (FTP) - Ports 20/21

FTP is used for transferring files between a client and a server over a network.

Port 20: Used for the data transfer channel.

Port 21: Used for the command/control channel to initiate connections.

ğŸ”’ Secure File Transfer Protocol (SFTP) - Port 22

SFTP is a secure version of FTP that uses SSH (Secure Shell) for encryption.

Port 22: The default port for SFTP, offering a secure method for file transfers over a network.

ğŸ” Secure Shell (SSH) - Port 22

SSH is a secure network protocol that allows secure remote access to devices over a network. It encrypts the communication between a client and a server.

Port 22: Commonly used for remote login and secure file transfers, ensuring privacy and integrity of data.

ğŸ“ Telnet - Port 23

Telnet is an older protocol used for remote access to servers and network devices. However, it transmits data in plaintext, making it insecure.

Port 23: Typically used for Telnet communication, but due to security vulnerabilities, itâ€™s rarely used today in favor of SSH.

ğŸ“§ Simple Mail Transfer Protocol (SMTP) - Port 25

SMTP is the protocol used for sending emails between servers.

Port 25: The default port for SMTP, primarily used for email transmission from mail client to mail server or between servers.

ğŸŒ Domain Name System (DNS) - Port 53

DNS is responsible for translating human-readable domain names into IP addresses that computers can understand.

Port 53: Used by DNS servers to listen for and respond to DNS queries.

ğŸŒ Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) - Ports 67/68

DHCP automatically assigns IP addresses to devices on a network, enabling them to communicate effectively.

Port 67: Used by the DHCP server to send messages to clients.

Port 68: Used by the DHCP client to receive configuration information from the server.

ğŸ—‚ï¸ Trivial File Transfer Protocol (TFTP) - Port 69

TFTP is a simplified version of FTP, used for transferring small files without authentication or encryption.

Port 69: Default port for TFTP, often used for bootstrapping devices or transferring configuration files in secure environments.

ğŸŒ Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) - Port 80

HTTP is the protocol used for transferring web pages over the internet. Itâ€™s the foundation of data communication on the World Wide Web.

Port 80: Default port for HTTP, allowing users to access websites and web applications.

â±ï¸ Network Time Protocol (NTP) - Port 123

NTP is used to synchronize the time across devices over a network, ensuring accurate timestamps for logs, transactions, and other time-sensitive data.

Port 123: The default port used by NTP servers and clients to request and synchronize time.

ğŸ“Š Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) - Ports 161/162

SNMP is used for managing and monitoring network devices like routers, switches, and servers.

Port 161: Used by SNMP agents to receive requests for data collection and status checks.

Port 162: Used by SNMP traps to send alerts or notifications about network events.

ğŸ“‡ Lightweight Directory Access Protocol (LDAP) - Port 389

LDAP is a protocol used for accessing and managing directory services (like Active Directory) that store organizational data (e.g., user credentials, devices).

Port 389: Default port for standard LDAP communication.

ğŸ”’ Hypertext Transfer Protocol Secure (HTTPS) - Port 443

HTTPS is the secure version of HTTP, using SSL/TLS to encrypt communications between a web browser and server to ensure privacy and integrity.

Port 443: Default port for HTTPS traffic, ensuring secure web browsing and data exchange.

ğŸ’» Server Message Block (SMB) - Port 445

SMB is a network file sharing protocol that allows applications to read and write to files and request services from server programs.

Port 445: Used for SMB communication, enabling file sharing over a network.

ğŸ“œ Syslog - Port 514

Syslog is a protocol used for sending log or event messages to a centralized server for analysis and storage.

Port 514: Default port used for sending and receiving syslog messages.

ğŸ“§ Simple Mail Transfer Protocol Secure (SMTPS) - Port 587

SMTPS is a secure version of SMTP, using TLS/SSL to encrypt email communication between clients and servers, ensuring privacy.

Port 587: Default port for submitting outbound email using encryption (with STARTTLS).

ğŸ” Lightweight Directory Access Protocol over SSL (LDAPS) - Port 636

LDAPS is the secure version of LDAP, encrypting directory services communications using SSL/TLS.

Port 636: Default port for encrypted LDAP communication.

ğŸ—ƒï¸ Structured Query Language (SQL) Server - Port 1433

SQL Server uses this protocol for database communication, allowing queries to interact with databases for data retrieval and management.

Port 1433: Default port for Microsoft SQL Serverâ€™s database service.

ğŸ–¥ï¸ Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) - Port 3389

RDP allows remote access to Windows computers, providing a graphical interface for users to interact with systems over a network.

Port 3389: Default port for RDP, used to establish remote desktop connections.

ğŸ“ Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) - Ports 5060/5061

SIP is used for initiating, maintaining, and terminating real-time communications like voice and video calls.

Port 5060: Default port for unencrypted SIP communication.

Port 5061: Default port for encrypted SIP communication using TLS.

ğŸŒ Internet Protocol (IP) Types

ğŸŒ Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP)

ICMP is used by network devices to send error messages and operational information, such as whether a service is reachable or a router can be reached.

Common use: Ping command, which uses ICMP Echo Request and Echo Reply messages to check the connectivity between devices.

ğŸ”Œ Transmission Control Protocol (TCP)

TCP is a connection-oriented protocol that ensures reliable data transfer. It manages error checking, data sequencing, and guarantees data arrives in order.

Common use: Web browsing (HTTP/HTTPS), email (SMTP), file transfer (FTP).

ğŸ“¦ User Datagram Protocol (UDP)

UDP is a connectionless protocol that doesn't guarantee delivery or order of data packets. Itâ€™s faster but less reliable than TCP, used where speed is critical.

Common use: Streaming video/audio, DNS queries, VoIP.

ğŸ”„ Generic Routing Encapsulation (GRE)

GRE is a tunneling protocol used to encapsulate and send any Layer 3 protocol over a Layer 3 network, often used for creating VPNs or connecting remote networks.

Common use: VPN connections and routing of multicast traffic.

ğŸ”’ Internet Protocol Security (IPSec)

IPSec is a suite of protocols used to secure IP communications by authenticating and encrypting each IP packet.

Common use: Secure communication over IP networks, particularly in VPNs.

ğŸ›¡ï¸ Authentication Header (AH): Provides packet-level authentication and integrity.

ğŸ”‘ Encapsulating Security Payload (ESP): Provides encryption and data integrity.

ğŸ”‘ Internet Key Exchange (IKE): Protocol used to establish a secure channel for IPSec by securely exchanging keys.

ğŸ“¡ Traffic Types

ğŸ“¤ Unicast

Unicast is a one-to-one communication where a message is sent from one device to another.

Common use: Standard internet browsing, file transfers.

ğŸ“¡ Multicast

Multicast allows one device to send a message to multiple devices at once, but only to those devices that are part of the multicast group.

Common use: Streaming media, conference calls, and software distribution to multiple clients.

ğŸ“­ Anycast

Anycast is a one-to-nearest communication where data is sent to the closest device (by routing distance) from a group of potential recipients.

Common use: DNS servers and content delivery networks (CDNs) for optimal routing to the nearest server.

ğŸ“¡ Broadcast

Broadcast sends a message from one device to all devices on the same network.

Common use: DHCP, ARP (Address Resolution Protocol), and certain network discovery protocols.
